title: 111_hr5588
content: The Medicare Enrollment Protection Act of 2010, also known as the "Medicare Part B Special Enrollment Period for Individuals Enrolled in COBRA Continuation Coverage," provides a special enrollment period for individuals with COBRA coverage. The Medicare Enrollment Protection Act of 2010 offers a special enrollment period for individuals enrolled in COBRA continuation coverage, allowing them to enroll in Medicare Part B after their initial enrollment period. The Medicare Enrollment Protection Act of 2010 provides a special enrollment period for individuals in COBRA continuation coverage to enroll in Medicare Part B after their initial enrollment period. This special enrollment can only be used once in a lifetime. COBRA continuation coverage refers to specific types of continuation coverage under various laws and does not include health flexible spending arrangements. The Medicare Enrollment Protection Act of 2010 allows individuals in COBRA continuation coverage to enroll in Medicare Part B during a special enrollment period. This special enrollment can only be used once in a lifetime and does not increase premiums. The Medicare Enrollment Protection Act of 2010 allows individuals in COBRA continuation coverage to enroll in Medicare Part B during a special enrollment period. The amendments made by this section take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act and apply to periods of COBRA continuation coverage before, on, or after such date. No special enrollment period shall begin before the first day of the first month that begins at least 45 days after the date of the enactment of this Act. The amendment applies to premiums for months beginning with the first month that begins at least 45 days after the date of the enactment of this Act. No special enrollment period shall begin before the first day of the first month that begins at least 45 days after the date of the enactment of this Act. The amendment applies to premiums for months beginning with the first month that begins at least 45 days after the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. CONTINUOUS OPEN MEDICARE PART B ENROLLMENT. The Medicare Enrollment Protection Act of 2010 introduces a continuous open enrollment period for individuals eligible for Medicare Part B. This period starts on the first day of the month when eligibility criteria are met, excluding initial enrollment or special enrollment periods. Individuals enrolling during a general enrollment period will be enrolled under that subsection unless specified otherwise. The Medicare Enrollment Protection Act of 2010 amends section 1395q(a)(2) by adding a new subparagraph (G) for individuals enrolling under subsection (m) of section 1837. Additionally, section 1839 is amended to increase the monthly premium for individuals enrolled during a continuous open enrollment period under section 1837(m). The Secretary may increase premiums based on enrollment in the insurance program under part B of title XVIII of the Social Security Act. A report to Congress must be submitted within 180 days of the Act's enactment, detailing premium increases and any related regulations. The Secretary can increase premiums based on enrollment in the insurance program under part B of title XVIII of the Social Security Act. A report to Congress must be submitted within 180 days of the Act's enactment, detailing premium increases, regulations, number and characteristics of enrollees, and costs not covered by premium increases. The amendments made by this section will take effect on the enactment date, with a 45-day waiting period before individuals can enroll in a continuous open enrollment period. SEC. 4 amends Section 1837(h) of the Social Security Act to allow special enrollment periods to correct errors, misrepresentations, or inaction by the federal government, group health plan, or plan sponsor. SEC. 5 focuses on coordinating Medicare Part B with American Health Benefit Exchanges. SEC. 5 amends Section 1837 of the Social Security Act to ensure coordination between Medicare Part B and American Health Benefit Exchanges for a smooth transition in enrollment. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress within 2 years of this Act on enrollment issues in Medicare Part B. The report will evaluate problems faced by individuals, assess the number of uninsured due to enrollment issues, and review efforts to educate employers on transitioning employees to Medicare Part B. The evaluation will include coordination of coverage for individuals with private health insurance eligible for Medicare part B, coordination between Medicare part B and American Health Benefit Exchanges, differences in regulations for age vs. disability eligibility, and efforts by Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services to provide equitable relief. The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services aim to provide equitable relief to individuals affected by misinformation or lack of information on Medicare part B enrollment.
